document.docAuthor: Orr, Michael C., Pitts, James P. & Griswold, Terry
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Anthophora curta var. peritomae Cockerell, 1905a: 271
( holotype : ♂ ; Alamosa, CO, USA ; coll. S.A. Johnson, 6 Aug. 1903 , at

subSubSection.paragraph:
Cleome
; CASENT, type 15469).
Anthophora peritomae var. interspersa Cockerell, 1907a: 397
(applied to 1905 type, same specimen as is given above).
Anthophora peritomae var. tinctula Cockerell, 1907a: 397
( holotype : female; Rociada, NM, USA ; coll. W.P. Cockerell, 8 Aug.,

at
Grindelia
; CASENT, type 15470). Syn. Michener, 1951 .

Female similar to male, except: Head: Mandible main blade enlarged into huge scoop; inferior tooth a mere corner, easily missed; maculated for under half of total length ( Fig. 41F ). Labral rim rounded. Clypeal maculation thicker, often surpassing half of clypeal height medially ( Fig. 41F ). Mesosoma: Midtibial spur apically curved; tan to orange. Basitibial plate circular distally, teardropped overall. Metasoma: T1–T4 with thicker apical appressed setal bands; T5 with appressed setae, sometimes reduced. T4 impunctate rim of moderate to extended length medially, roughly triangular. Anal fimbria strongly triangular, covering clearly over third and usually nearly half of T5 length medially. Pubescence: See
Fig. 46F
. Vertex and scutum usually darker; hindbasitarsal brush medium to dark brown; anal fimbria black to dark brown, sometimes invaded by light below; S5 dark apicomedially, usually obscured by light.

Distribution. See Fig. 23 . Found throughout much of west, typically montane in hotter areas, occupying broader range of environments in colder areas. Present in USA : Utah , Colorado , New Mexico , Wyoming , Arizona , Nevada , California , Montana , Idaho , North Dakota , likely Oregon , likely Washington , likely Texas , possibly South Dakota , possibly Nebraska , possibly Oklahoma ; Canada : Alberta , British Columbia , Saskatchewan ; Mexico : possibly Chihuahua . Ecoregional habitance is as follows, based on 837 specimen records: 15 ecoregions total: Colorado Plateau shrublands (609=74.8%), Great Basin shrub steppe (71=8.7%), Wasatch and Uinta montane forests (29=3.6%), Wyoming Basin shrub steppe (24=2.9%), Colorado Rockies forests (24=2.9%), Arizona Mountains forests (12=1.5%), Northern mixed grasslands (12=1.5%), Chihuahuan Desert (11=1.4%), Northern short grasslands (10=1.2%), Mojave Desert (4≤1%), Western short grasslands (3≤1%), Snake-Columbia shrub steppe (2≤1%), Sonoran Desert (1≤1%), Eastern Cascades forests (1≤1%), Okanagan dry forests (1≤1%).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 23. Distribution of
Anthophora peritomae
. Generated with 837 specimen records from 205 locations.

subSubSection.paragraph: Phenology. Recorded from April–October, almost exclusively late summer and fall, most common in August– October. Likely univoltine, few spring records suggestive of opportunistic emergence.

Floral specialization. Specialist on Asteraceae , with great breadth, likely enabling its large distribution. Primary recorded visits by 296 females include: Family Asteraceae (100% [others constitute <1%]); Genus
Chrysothamnus
(33%),
Ericameria
(21%), “
Aster
” (13%) [“
Aster
” was used prior to recent taxonomic changes, can refer to a number of genera]; Species
Ericameria nauseosa
(19%). 510 total floral records from four families include:
Asteraceae
( 211 ♂ 294 ♀ ):
Aster chilensis
3 ♂ 6 ♀ ,
Aster falcatus
2 ♂ 14 ♀ ,
Aster glaucodes
1 ♀ ,

sp. 4 ♂ 19 ♀ ,

sp. 3 ♂ 8 ♀ ,

Comments. This is the only confirmed communal species of A . (
Micranthophora
) ( Torchio 1971 ). It may be that selection to work together and share costs was exerted by the hardness of sandstone, which this species excavates. Further study of other species is necessary to determine whether or not the communal behavior of
A . peritomae
is truly unique. This is one of few A . (
Micranthophora
) for which predation has been documented; a single male bee is pinned with a
Phidippus Koch
male ( Salticidae ) from Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument (BBSL414081).
